text:
Welcome back to our Silicon
Valley and the US government speaker series. Today our session will
focus on Databricks.

Many of us know Databricks and
their commercial use cases. And today we'll discuss how
the company has been expanding

beyond that to build
their data intelligence platform for federal agencies
and the government sector.

So from Databricks, we
have Rory Patterson, thanks for joining us today,
Chair of Databricks federal. And we also have over here
In-Q-Tel's CEO Steve Bowsher.

In-Q-Tel' an investor in
Databricks and Steve will be moderating the discussion. So Steve and Rory, over to you.
Thank you. Great. Thanks, Ernestine. Can everyone hear me all right? Good. And good to see everybody again.

This is my second time
moderating a conversation. I'm very excited to
have Rory here with us. We're going to go through
a series of questions

probably over the next
half hour, 35 minutes, and then we'll
break for questions

from the audience for the
last 10 or 15 minutes. But I did want to offer
up-- because this happened

to me in a previous session. It seemed to work well. If there's a question
you're passionate about, let's not wait till the end.

Raise your hand in the middle,
and we'll go right to you and you can follow up on
what's being said right there. Does that sound good?

All right. Great. So Rory, first of all, welcome. Thank you for taking the
time here to come down and talk to the class today.

Maybe if you could, just-- because I think you have a
really interesting background that I think will allow people
to understand the perspective

that you're about
to share with us. So tell us a little bit
about your background first on the government
side and then at Databricks.

Started off as an
army intel officer. Spent about seven
years in the army.

And my last
assignment was working for a joint command
between NSA and the army

called network warfare, which
eventually became US Cyber Command. So I was like the first
100 employees there.

After that, they wouldn't
let me go back to the army. So I became a blue
badger up at Fort Meade

and spent the next seven years
in the intelligence community. During the end of my time
there, I spent a lot of time

with commercial
technology looking at the balance between build
versus buy inside the agency,

and I eventually left
and moved out here and worked for a security
company called Splunk.

It just got bought by Cisco. It was actually an
amazing security company. It's a indexed search.

It's pretty amazing
for what it does. Spent about four years there. I started off actually
coming into their security

organization, and then ended
up being the chief of staff to the CEO there for the
last three years I was there.

And then I got to
work for-- then Ali called me about four
years ago and asked me to come work for Databricks.

So I've been working
for him ever since. As both chief of staff, but
also chairman or general manager

of the federal business. Yeah about a year
into my time there, Ali said, hey, we need to relook
at our public sector business

and he asked me to
take a look at it. And about two months
later, he said, this is a much better
plan than the one we had

and so I took it
over from there. It's a good lesson. If you come up
with a great plan, people are going to ask you
to execute on it so you better

believe in your plan. Everything is owned by doers. If you do the work, you
will eventually own it.

That's the difference. It's not like oh,
title doesn't matter, it's like who's
going to do the work and I think that's recognized
just about everywhere.

Good. So how do you split your
time between the chief of staff functions and
the federal function.

If you ask Ali, it's 90/10
in support of Chief of Staff functions, but it turns
out to be about 50-50.

I spend about 50% of my
time with the government. And describe what Databricks
does today and sort

of how it's evolved to where
it is today before we get into the government aspect of-- Yeah, of course. Databricks started off as
a commercialized offering

of Apache Spark. The founders invented
Apache Spark, which is like distributed compute. It's like, I would
say, de facto--

You have to admit
they were at Berkeley. Yes they were all PhD
grad students up at Cal.

And it's a great story if
you had a chance to read up on how that all got started. But it's distributed compute.

I think it's like the foundation
of most machine learning. So even if you're
not using Databricks, you're using Spark everywhere.

I think it's like a
billion downloads a year. And even if you're
not using Databricks

and you're not using EMR, which
is based on Spark or Dataproc at GCP, or you just
name the product,

every cloud has bought one. If you've homegrown it and
you've built it like Netflix, you're still using Apache
Spark under the hood.

And where the company has
come over the last 10 years is really moving away from
just being a commercial cloud

offering of Apache Spark to
being a set of services that are well integrated together. So there's a data warehouse,
there's a governance model,

there's a lot of
streaming technology. And you're really
just trying to make what took Netflix 10 years to
build as a data platform, why

shouldn't you just be able to
buy that and do Disney streaming or Paramount or overnight. Why would you have to
invest the 2000 engineers

that it would take to build
something and maintain it, when you could just buy it
and run it as a SaaS offering.

Yeah, it's actually a very
interesting story, one that I got to view
from the boardroom. Which is there are a number
of companies out there,

and we've invested
in several of them, that are basically just
commercializing an open source project. And there's certain
value in doing that

but those companies tend
to reach a certain ceiling of impact and value.

And what the Databricks team
did that was so impressive was they started out doing
that, but then they figured out,

all right, what is the
other set of features, the other set of
services that you really need to do in order to solve
the problem completely.

And they built those in
a proprietary manner, wrapped that on top of the open
source aspects of Apache Spark,

and built one of the more
valuable private companies that we have in the country
right now, and one that I'm sure

will eventually be a very
valuable public company as well. So Databricks launched
had huge success

in the commercial sector. It's really-- it's the only
company I've ever been involved with, as an investor, that
for three straight years

had the July board
meeting, said, we're going to exceed our
plan for the year by so much that we're going to need
to raise the target.

So something that almost never
happens to you as an investor. So it was just a
fantastic experience.

But talk about the
applicability to government. What are the government
problems out there that Databricks solves?

And then we'll talk about
how the strategy has evolved over time. Yeah of course. So I mean I think the
applicability is just about

everywhere because it's--
we're a data and AI company. So you figure everywhere
in the government is a data problem from
state and local issues.

Like the state of California I
think some of the biggest budget is spent on transportation
and health care. We help solve some
of those problems.

You think about integrating
data across agencies, especially at the state level.

That's another big use
case that we solve. At the federal level,
some of the larger,

like AI use cases that we're
solving is immigration. So like all the
bottlenecks to get people

through the immigration
process, we actually accelerate all of it. It's almost all sitting
on Databricks today. It's-- the Undersecretary of DHS
came by our offices about six

months ago. And like un-- Unprompted. Unprompted like someone
else, asked him like, hey,

what's the number one
AI use case in DHS? And he said, by far it's
Databricks with customs.

So it's like the immigration
process was broken, and now most of it's
automated, through Databricks, which is pretty amazing because
we think that not only helps us

as a company bring
in new people, but helps folks get
into the country. But also, like, customs
and Border Patrol,

there's a huge fentanyl use case
to help stop fentanyl coming into the country.

What else? Postal service users it. You'd be shocked, but some of
the things that you expect out

of an Amazon like where's
my package right now, Postal service didn't have
that stuff five years ago

and today it does. A lot of that's on the
backs of Databricks.

Department of Transportation,
a lot of the projections and modeling about what
future transportation needs are going to be.

I could go on and on. The Department of
Defense, Space Force. There's a ton of
use cases there.

And I think a lot of it is just
taking advantage of the data that you already have. And I don't think the government
does a great job of that

without having to always upgrade
your entire technology stack, because that's
just not a reality for these large organizations.

You have to be able to
leverage some of the data where it stands. Those are some of
the biggest cases.

And then, of course, like our
work with the intelligence community, they
don't really like me talking about their use cases.

Understood and we'll get into
some of the non-intelligence use cases in a second a
little bit more detail.

So there's a lot
of applicability for your technology
to the government.

The original strategy to
go after the government, though, was to
modify the product.

Tell everyone a little
bit about why that was and what worked and didn't
work with that strategy? Yeah, I think a lot of
companies do this right.

It's hard to meet the
security and compliance requirements of the government. So a lot of companies that
see the strategy as being SaaS

and I mean, there's not a lot
of on prem companies being built today, let's be honest. But if you want to
sell to the government,

they want to buy on
prem in two ways. They want the legacy pricing. And they also say, hey, I'll
take on all the security

controls within my own AZ. So they'll like-- they'll-- so a lot of companies, including
Databricks, fork their code

and they build an on-prem
version of their product to meet the needs
of the government and quickly get a
juice of revenue.

You'd be surprised, but probably
the top 10 software companies have done this. I think that most of them
thinks it's a mistake.

And in hindsight,
everyone's like oh, I wish I hadn't done that, but
it's really hard to get out of that place where
you've like-- you've

started to generate revenue,
there's demand for it, but you really should be
selling this SaaS offering.

The other thing that's really
hard is once you fork the code, it's really hard to keep
maintaining that code base. So what ended up happening
is when I got here

you could see that the forked
on-prem code was already falling behind. But then, within
the next 24 months,

we were going to have this
explosion of new features and new products that
were going to come out, and there was no way that it
was going to be able to keep up.

So we stopped. We just like froze it. And we'll come down in a second. But just-- you brought up
a really interesting point

that I don't want to drive by
too fast, which is when you're

a software as a
service company, SaaS, you get paid on a monthly
recurring revenue basis.

And there might be some of
upfront fee for installation or customization, but then
you get paid a monthly fee,

typically based on
some of usage metric. And if you're a good
software application, typically you increase
that over time

because more and more users
want to take advantage of you within that organization. It's an incredibly profitable
business model when

you get to a certain scale. Because all of a
sudden you're getting paid on recurring revenue basis,
you've built this software once,

you have lots of
different people using it. It's a fantastic business. But it is a hard
business to scale

because you're not getting that
juice that you referred to. I like that phrase, the juice
of the initial upfront payment

that the traditional legacy
software companies used to get. Which legacy software
companies used to sort of say,

or it might even be
a perpetual license. But then in a couple of
years, the software company is going to come out with a
new version of the product

with a new set of features and
say that perpetual license is only good for the old thing. You got to pay
for the new thing.

And so it is tempting for
software companies, when they're in that early
stage and they're trying to show revenue
growth to their investors,

raise more money to fund all
the development work and the go to market stuff they need to
do to try and juice the revenue

by doing these on-prem deals. But I mean, how often do you
guys update your SaaS version?

Every day, every
week, every month? 400 times a week. 400 times a week. That's unbelievable.

To 75 cloud regions
on three clouds. So on-- there's a GCP and
Azure and an AWS region

and there's 75
across those three. So these software as a service
applications are really living dynamic things and
these on-prem versions

are static snapshot, right? And literally by the time
you get it installed,

you're probably already
two weeks behind that. And over time,
that technical debt

just becomes bigger and bigger. But the government is
comfortable with that. And when the government is
comfortable with something,

it is a big freight
train going down the path that's hard to
stop and hard to turn.

So when you figure figured out
that the right strategy for you guys was to sunset or
freeze the on-prem version

and move the customers
to the SaaS version, what was the
resistance they met,

and how did you overcome
that resistance? Yeah I mean, I think
the first resistance was with our own team at the time.

So you have sales guys who are-- Sales team. --commissioned in a certain way. That's right. They're like, hey, they'll
never buy the cloud version.

I think also 70% of our
revenue, at the time, was with on-prem and 30% of it--

for the federal business,
not for the company. For the federal business,
70% of the revenue was coming in from
on-prem version.

And they saw that
as the cache cow. They saw that as they
don't need the other stuff. They don't even care that these
new things are coming out.

But it takes years to go
through all those compliance investments, which is
why it takes forever

for companies to do it. So it's not seeing out
one year or 24 months, it's like a five-year
strategy to move to the cloud.

We're only in year
three of it right now. But it took us-- the
first year was OK,

and reporting on
top of commercial. Quite honestly, and
my encouragement is like, this is a tough trade
off for software companies

as they first get started. But security is like
a first class citizen. I don't think it's
always that way.

But the government, in order for
you to be government certified, it's called FedRAMP, or
at least the lowest level

is called FedRAMP
moderate, you have to have all these controls in
place, and you get audited, and you have to report
if you have violations

and things like that. I'd encourage everyone to
start with that in mind. That's thing number one. It's hard to go
back and re-engineer

those things because you're
either architected for it or you're not. There's another
dirty little phrase

in the government called
authority to operate or ATO. And ATO is basically permission
from the security people

at these agencies
for your software to run on their networks. And ATO is something that trips
up a lot of commercial software

companies trying to sell it to
the government, where they don't realize just the amount
of work that you need

to do to be certified,
whether it's FedRAMP or whatever version
you're getting. Yeah. So we spent the first
12 months to build out

the new infrastructure. We rolled that out, and then we
slowly migrated every customer away and then
started the next one.

So it's like FedRAMP,
GovCloud, GovCloud il5,

which is what the DOD uses. We finally just got our
il5 ATO three weeks ago,

so it was almost three
years into it to get there. And now we're slowly moving
all those DOD customers

onto the Cloud product,
which is great. But we're not creating
any more debt. So no one's selling or
buying the old product.

And then they have
the same product that you pick your
commercial customer--

Yes. --some big bank in Wall
Street or some big consumer

facing company, they're
getting the same version. When you update a new
feature or new service to the commercial product,
they're getting it as well.

They get it about two
weeks later, but only because we have to go through
all the compliance checks before we update it. But it feels like--

I mean, it feels
like light speed compared to what they
were getting before. Yeah. Plus they need all
the capabilities.

That's my-- I left
the government to make sure that commercial
software was actually used in the government.

That was my-- when
I left, my boss was like, I can't
believe you're leaving. And I'm like, I will help you. I will bring back commercial--

I just haven't done
it fast enough. But like, that's been my
passion is to do that. So I think, at this point,
at least at Databricks,

we're getting there. It's a very NSA
response, by the way. I can't believe
you're leaving us. So-- They have a great alumni.

I mean, I'm sure
the school does too, but they have a great
Alumni Association there. Yeah. Yeah. So you talked about
the resistance

from your salespeople. You talked about
the certifications you had to go through. What about convincing
the government customers

that it's OK for their data
to leave their four walls and go out to your cloud
and then come back to them.

Was that a resistance
that you had to overcome and how did you do that? Yeah I mean, I think
the benefit to us

is that AWS, kind of,
broke all the glass here. So as long as you're
sitting inside of AWS or inside of Azure, you're,
kind of like their data

already exists there. It exists in S3 and
S3 is multi-tenant, or it exists in ADLs,
if you're on Azure.

And so like that data
already resides there. So if we can just take
advantage of it staying in that environment, we're
pretty fortunate that they

broke that glass. I think when it comes
to ATO everyone still

is-- the government
is still new at this. To be critical of the
government for a second, It.

Took them what will
eventually be like nine months to just look at our packet
to certify us for GovCloud.

So even though,
back in April, we submitted all of
our paperwork, we have an infrastructure
that's sitting there.

It costs us about--
to sit empty, it costs us about $200,000 a
month just to sit there with no customers.

It sat there with no
customers for nine months, and we're still waiting for
the government to certify it. It doesn't take them nine
months to actually go

through the packet. It's just-- it's done with-- There's a line and
I think there's only one employee or something. Yeah. Right, yeah.

So you get that going. You're still not on the
top secret networks.

That's a whole
other certification that you have to go through. Yeah our on prem version is
on the top secret network,

and we're in discussions with
the intelligence community about how to put the
commercial product there. Yep. Yep. OK.

But the customers that you
do have on the cloud product,

talk about how that
reduced barriers to buying and also allowed you to sell
and not just existing features,

but new features that
are coming soon to them. Yeah, I mean, the commercial
product, you just click and use,

so it's a lot easier to leverage
any of the capabilities there. But also a lot of these
government agencies

already have contracts
with AWS or Azure where they can just
purchase and buy, and they don't actually have to
go through a new contract award.

So through the marketplace,
it's actually way easier to purchase than it is to
purchase an outside product. Plus, all their data already
sits in S3 or ADLs on Azure.

So you're just accessing
data that already sits there. What's harder is when the
government hasn't migrated

all of their data
to the cloud, then you're still trying
to figure out how to leverage that or access
that data for your purposes.

But I think there's probably a
shift, two or three years ago, where not only has
the government moved a significant amount of data,
I'd say it's probably like 30%.

The DOD and the IC are
probably a little bit higher, but the federal government
is probably around 30%.

As they shift more
data there, the easier it is to attack it and analyze
it and make value out of it.

I think our challenge
now is like, how do you get them to move
more data to the cloud faster.

There's no way they're going
to take advantage of on-prem Netezza or on-prem Oracle.

None of that's going
to be modernized, it's just like a delay
until it gets to the cloud and then you can have more
value created on top of it.

Yeah. So if you don't mind,
let's dig into one or two of these use cases
a little bit more detail.

I don't whether you want to do
DHS or one of the other ones, but talk about what
the problem was--

what the state of the world
was before you guys got there, and the impact you
guys delivered.

Yeah, maybe I'll take
one of the DOD agencies. OK, sure. The DOD's Chief Digital and
Artificial Intelligence Office,

CDAo had a program called ADVANA
which is their attempt to bring

in 1,000 different data sets
about everything from finance to logistics to
personnel, about the DOD.

And you can imagine
the DOD is a big place, but it's also for
services that feel like they have autonomy
over their own data

and can do whatever
they want to with it. And so like asking
simple questions like, how much ammunition do I
have here could take two months.

How many people do I have
to deploy to this location? What's my fuel reserve
at this spot, like it

takes months and months. But also because the
systems are so old, they're paying
billions of dollars

every month out to
all sorts of folks. And it's really hard to
reconcile those things long term, like
dollars being spent.

So they were able to-- and by the way, it's
not just Databricks, but it's a lot of other
technologies there

and a great leadership team. But they were-- I think they're
at like 800 of those data sources are integrated together
today using Databricks.

And I think the
big transformation there is the awakening
that you can actually

go from days or months
to accessing and getting these answers to
hours or minutes.

But it's not just like-- it's not just the DOD
that's in this place. Like we work with a large
commercial bank that

used to wait 10 hours
to reconcile all their financial transactions,
which you'd be surprised,

but you have your
banking statements and you withdraw money
or you transfer money, and it's like 10 hours later,
largest bank on the planet,

they know what
happened 10 hours ago and now it's down
to three seconds.

So like, imagine if
that's true for-- It's really unifying
all the data sources. It's unifying--
but it's also being able to move it that quickly.

Yeah. Oh, yeah. Like with the
analogy that we make is like if you-- because
they're like a lot of people have to conceptualize these
machine-learning models

with things that they're getting
like recommendations engines. Like I always think, how
ridiculous would it be

if you're-- the next video
you're going to watch on Disney streaming
or whatever Netflix or whatever was
like 10 hours old.

It's instantaneous. They looked at every
user at every moment and they said now you
have watched these videos

and everyone on the
planet has also done it. And I know right now what
I should recommend to you and it's brand new all the time.

It's ridiculous that you'd
be like, well, 10 hours to get your transactions,
but Netflix has figured out how to do the same exact thing.

It's all just
distributed compute. So the DOD is in the same place.

I think that they
told-- the number they told us was
roughly $1 billion that they saved in
payments that they didn't

know they were over making. So they're like, oh, we were
paying the same bill many times.

You're like, I'm surprised
that companies didn't speak up, but maybe they don't.

And by the way, that's-- if
you read in the paper about DOD having failed eight or
nine straight audits,

this is the problem that
you're trying to solve is one of the problems
that drives that. Which is the DOD is
so big and so vast

that it can't answer
questions like, all right, where's all my
manpower deployed, and where's all my ammunition
stored, how much of-- how many

corporals do I have? How many sergeants do I have? You think that'd be very
simple and easy to answer, but it's really complex
because the data is

in all sorts of different silos
and unifying it, accessing it and analyzing it in real
time just doesn't exist.

And they can't even get it done
in a year to answer your audit. So it's a great
juicy problem one

that you guys are delivering
real impact against. So where are you going next? Where's the product
roadmap here?

And as you think about
that product roadmap, what are some of the future
problems that you think you're going to try
and solve here with those?

Yeah I mean I think there's
a-- just like everywhere else, there's a manpower issue,
and there's probably

an expertise issue. But I think the
government does a-- I think the government is used
to throwing humans at problems

instead of technology. So there's a lot of
consultants out there working for the government full time.

I think there's hundreds
of thousands of them non-government employees
that are, like, augmenting the government.

My guess is that 50% of
them could be replaced with really great software. They're doing trivial
tasks in most cases.

So I think there's a lot
of opportunity there. We've really embraced a lot
of the generative AI and LLMs

and agents. And I think that that's the
future for the government. Our platform is on
the government clouds

is fully able to access those. So I think there's a lot
of opportunity to both do a better job of accessing data.

I think you guys are smarter
than me about this stuff. But like there-- these
large language models

aren't the answer to
questions, they're the interface to getting
answers to questions. So I think if you think
about compound agent systems

and you think
about the right way to leverage these technologies. The government has silo after
silo after silo of data sets,

the question is, it's really
hard to ask the right question to get the right answer. But I think LLMs can help there.

So I think we're headed
in that direction. And I think because
of the way we've architected the platform,
once you get the data in

and you have great governance. You can build whatever
you want to on top of it. And I think that instead of
having the government have

software engineers
building horrible software, they should have more
application developers that

are actually building on
top of great technology. And if we can just
get them more and more direct contracts to buy
with commercial vendors,

I think they'll be
in a better spot and let the government
be really good at what it needs to be good at. Back at the Fort, no one's going
to be better at cryptography

than them. But do they really
need to build some of these commercial
technologies? Probably not. They don't, but
they think they do.

So we're working on that. All right, a couple of last
questions here and then

we'll go on to the
Q&A section here.

In your role as chief
of staff, obviously you get to see all the great
work you guys are doing for your commercial
customers, you also

see what you're doing for
the government customers. Compare and contrast
the government as a customer versus
the commercial.

If you're a young
entrepreneur or thinking about starting a
company, why would you even think about
servicing the government

with some of the challenges
that you've already mentioned? Yeah I mean, I think
the way I would

think about it is less about
servicing one or the other, as more as if you think that
you're going to eventually go

after the government customers,
it's better to start early with the investments that are
required in the platform as

opposed go to market. There's a lot of
disadvantages to investing in these things from a
go to market perspective,

because the sales
cycles are long. It's 12 to 18 months instead
of three to six months in a lot of cases.

But a lot of the
security requirements that the government
wants, eventually you're going to get to financial
institutions and health that

want very, very similar
things so you might as well go after those first. Because those are
going to be your three biggest target
audiences anyways.

If you include government,
financial services and healthcare of any
large software company,

you're talking about
60% of their revenue. So eventually,
you're going to go after it, you might as well
start investing in those things

up front and then decide, well,
if I've invested in the security and compliance, I can decide
later on to go after the go

to market and go after
those customers directly. Now, why would you do it?

I think that we all have a
vested interest in the success of our government.

I think that the
better off they are, the better off we are so I
think there's a benefit there.

And if I could replace many
people with software there where they could cut the costs and be
more efficient, it's good for me

too. I hate standing
in line at the DMV or anywhere else
so might as well give them the best software.

Great. All right. One last question, then. You had a really
interesting career.

You went into the military
right out of college, then you did work for government
agencies as a civilian,

then you went and worked for
two great technology companies. We have a bunch of people
here that are probably

thinking, in some
form or another, hey, what do I do
in a year or two. Do you have any advice for them?

You're only young once
so go do something that you won't get to do. Go do something that
you're passionate about.

I have a 24-year-old son, and
that's my advice to him so I guess it's the same
advice to you guys. Which is go do the thing that
you can only do in your 20s

or 30s and then you'll
always come back. Like there's always the obvious
thing to come back and do.

Yeah. I had a lot of fun in
the army, but of course, like I joined because
there was a war. And now that there's
no war, there's

no reason to be in the
army, in my opinion. I mean, there should-- other people should
be in the army, just I didn't want to be there.

And in the government, I got to
do things that no one will ever get to do. Just think about it.

I was part of a organization
called Network Warfare. What do you think we did? So there's a lot of cool
things to do there that you

can't do anywhere else. Yeah. But I would encourage
everybody, even if you're not

going to go work
for the government or join the military,
which isn't for everyone, is to think about the
benefits that you can bring

to the country, whether or not
it's securing things or bringing

innovation to the government
or actually just bringing innovation to our economy. That's also a way of
continuing to secure

our country is like
making the economy strong and I think that this is
a great place to do it. Great. All right.

With that, I'll start with
questions from the audience. I think for the video purposes,
I will repeat your question

when it gets asked. But if you have any questions,
please raise your hand.

OK. Just kind of curious-- So the question is
talk a little bit about the competitive
landscape that's out there.

In specific Snowflake
is an obvious competitor in the compound here plays
in this space as well.

I think about the two
of them differently. I think Snowflake is a
really great data warehouse.

It's like a modern
Oracle in the cloud. And I think that that
solves some problems,

I don't think it
solves every problem. I think if you had the
chance to rebuild your data

platform today,
you'd pick something that was built to handle both
structured and unstructured data. And so that's probably like my--

that doesn't mean there's not
a lot of great uses for a data warehouse it's just
whatever you're built for, that's what you're great at.

But yeah, it's a good company. I think having competition
is a great thing. So even if you're like--

the more people that are
competing for your market means that there's
a real market there. It stinks to be
by yourself alone.

You're probably not
growing very fast, and there's probably not
much long-term opportunity. So I think it's great
to have of competition.

I think when it
comes to Palantir, I think that Palantir has done
a great job being very mission

first for the government. They're a little bit
like-- they're like exactly the opposite from us in this--
and by the way I'm really

good friends with
the CTO over there. And we're also like building a
partnership with them right now

so they're a great company. But I think that they built
their platform mission down

or stack down. And so like the UI is the
most amazing UI anyone's ever interfaced with before.

I actually used it
in the government. I was a big advocate
while I was there. But then as you
get into the data

ingestion, and those
things, I think it becomes more complicated. So I think they're
a great partner. I think what Palantir
is doing, though,

is really good
for the government because they're disrupting
this mindset of it should take you three
years to build something.

And they're like, nope, we can
come in firm, fixed, price it. We'll build it for
you in six months. They hire wicked smart
people in every part

of their organization, and
they go and deploy quickly. And I think if the
government could get used to that model of
you should expect something

in six months and not six years,
it's better for everybody. By the way, as an investor,
it's a flag for us

when there's no competition. When an entrepreneur is
pitching us and we say,

how do you think
about your competitor. And like well, we
have no competition. No one else can do
what we're doing.

Our response to
that is like, well, if this was an important
enough problem, there'd be other people out
there trying to solve it.

So it's kind of a rookie
mistake by certain inexperienced

entrepreneurs to come into
venture pitches and say, we don't have any competition
because they think that's helping them
and it really doesn't.

Other questions? Back there. Thinking about the future
private companies--

So the question
is there's a trend with a number of large
private tech companies

out there for them to go
on prem in the same way that the government has
been interested in on prem.

Will those large

of dealing with less than

to respond to that,

given their desire to keep

of the question?

OK, great. Yeah. And do you think this is in
the context of just keeping their data there or are
you thinking like Gen AI,

LLM companies or are
you thinking like-- I'm trying to make
sure I differentiate between a specific company,
in general, where you're

thinking about going on prem. I would think Google
would go in that direction if they haven't already.

You probably work with a
large language model company and also machine learning right. This interface.

So on prem entirely
closed circuit. But when it becomes
totally closed build an AI system trained the
way we want with the information

we want it to be integrated
into our operations. Yeah I mean, I think
it's a small market.

I think that's
unfortunate reality is-- and I don't want to comment
on somebody else's business, but I think that AWS
tried this, and I think

that they walked away from it. And I think that Google is
actually going down this path right now. We'll see if they eventually
are successful there.

But I think the challenges
are eventually you get back into the hardware
business and not the software

business because you've
gone into their VPC. And so you're like,
hey, well, then you're selling them hardware
and you're like, what's

the margins on hardware and
is that the business model you're really in. You have to really think
about that, as a business, because you get in
the software business,

you're expecting to make a
certain amount of margins and your investors are
thinking about those margins. And then all of a sudden,
you're in the hardware business

and those margins are horrible. So you have to think about that. I think-- if you're
thinking of--

I think the government,
this is my perspective, thinks it's more unique
than it really is.

I also think that when you're
thinking about training a model, there's three minds.

One is the big
Anthropics and OpenAI and Bard's are going to rule
everything in the world.

There's the I can build
my own small model, and it will be more
efficient, and maybe it'll just be trained to
do the thing I really

care about for this purpose. And it will not only be
more efficient from a cost perspective, but energy and
everything else as well.

And then there's like-- what you're saying
is like, I need to build for this
very specific--

like every model will have
its own specific use case or whatever. I'll have a doctor model or
I'll have a mechanical model.

I think it's really
expensive to update models,

and it's not worth it. You're-- like, instead of
using the model as the answer for your questions, you'll
be using it as an interface

to serve up to get to the
answer to your questions. That'll sit somewhere else that
I can update instantaneously.

It'll sit on some index or a
vector database or something. And you'll be able to ask it
questions through the model.

But I don't think you'll want
to update those models even monthly. The challenge will be is like
lineage and understanding, hey,

how did you get that answer. And you're like,
well, last month it came to that conclusion this
way because the weights changed, because I updated the model.

Like it's not going to happen. So I think you're going to-- I think there'll be
some resistance to that.

I also-- I think that
we'll get better and better at these models. Like I still think that
we're in the early days,

like the fact that it will
cost us a couple hundred million dollars to build
these things is ridiculous. I think it will like-- the cost
will come down dramatically.

We did it. We bought a company and we
built a model for $10 million.

And it was like equivalent
to ChatGPT 3.5 I think. At the time, it
was, like, amazing.

But for $10 million. It wasn't just it
was amazing, it was amazing for
$10 million bucks.

I think that that price will
come way down as more resources become available. The challenge is will
we have the energy

to run all these
models simultaneously? How will we think about that? Yeah, I think it's
still early days on

whether or not people need
a really optimized model. I think there's
several use cases where that could be
applicable, but you'd

have to get like price
performance down there. And I don't know that anyone's
done all the work on that to say, like I've
built my own model,

and now that model
just does this. But it's super efficient, both
from a compute, energy, accuracy

perspective. And then how much more accurate
is that than just leveraging a big model and fine-tuning it.

That, I think, is
still be determined. Yeah I mean, as someone
who's invested in multiple of those companies you just
described, the specificity

around just how accurate
one model is versus another, how that accuracy
changes over time

and what the real cost of
delivering that answer is, we're still in the early days of
measuring that and figuring that

out. And the companies that
speak confidently about that are kind of kidding
themselves, I think.

I do, by the way, think
that if we can get this to the government, like
top secret network,

I think there's a lot of
data that goes underexplored because we don't know
how to access it.

And I think these models could
help us more effectively access it because they're just
better at writing statements.

Like converting from
hey, what's your question to understand the context. If you go back and rename
large language models,

you'd probably name them large
context modules or models, because that's
really what it is.

It's like-- it understands that
when you say how many chairs are in this room, it counts
this stool because it just

counts stools as chairs
because it has four legs. But if you were
to just like type a SQL statement that said
how many chairs in the room,

it wouldn't count the stools. Well, imagine when
you're thinking in that context of well,
did you mean patio furniture

or benches or couches? It understands what you mean. And then it asks that a
huge like amount of data,

and then it provides you
all that rich context. We used to have this problem
because if you don't classify

your data appropriately, and
it's really hard to do it, you could ask
questions, back at where I worked in the government.

And if you, like, I said, show
me all the things in China. If someone hadn't tagged
a report that Shanghai was

in China, it wouldn't produce
those results because it just didn't. You just didn't ask the
question appropriately

and the data wasn't
tagged effectively. But these LLMs provide
us the opportunity to like I don't wanna say stupid
questions smart or stupid people

smart or whatever, but it's
just like-- it will just do a better job at
being more efficient, and understanding the full
richness of all the data

that you have available and then
providing you those results. I think there's a massive
opportunity for us here in the
government to do that.

And every-- not just
in the government, but everywhere, but
especially the government. Thanks. Other questions here.

So the question was you
mentioned marketplaces. Databricks had its
own marketplace.

Can you talk about the
opportunities and challenges and what has worked,
I think, and hasn't worked with your marketplace?

Yeah, I think that we're in
the early days of Databricks, what we'll call-- what
we refer to as built on,

which is a place where companies
can come and say like, hey, Databricks already exists, you
already have access to so much

of the data, I just want
to build an application on top of Databricks instead
of starting bottom up.

I think we're in the
early days of that. I think it's challenging
because there's so much friction

between companies and do it
yourself and the go to market

team. Like those-- that
becomes the friction area between building a
great go to market. If I look at the best
marketplace, it's probably AWS.

And the reason why is that
they're customer first, but they've also
done a great job of--

they understand what their
biggest moneymaker is, which is storage and
compute, and they're going to get that no matter
what they sell on top.

So if they're buy-- if you're in the marketplace
and you're a customer and you want to buy
Databricks or EMR, AWS wins.

They would win more with
EMR than Databricks, but they're going
to win just enough and they've like
figured that out.

And so they encourage
the competition. And in fact they're
super customer-centric. So they'll be whatever
the customer wants,

we're going to endorse. Where I think if you're
competitive against that marketplace, you're like,
well, I could build it myself,

or I have an internal product,
and this marketplace is selling something that's
competitive with me, you're diminishing
your own revenue growth

where you have to
really figure that out. But I think we're in early
days because you also have to build your platform to
be like open APIs, open SDKs

so that people can build
comfortably and confidently on top of it. I think that'll take off in
the next couple of years here.

But it's definitely a
benefit to us and to others because you could also inherit
all the governance and security

controls. So you'd really have to
think, if I'm going to--

there's a lot of technologies
that are probably ripe for disruption right now. Which are like-- think
about anything that

was built 15 or 20 years ago. The next Workday,
is that company

going to be built
from the ground up, or are they just going to take
a technology like Databricks and build it on top.

Or the next Salesforce or the
next, you name the application, I think those are
all going to get

rebuilt. And I think they
could get easily rebuilt on top of a Databricks so we
have to figure those things out. But I don't see--

If you're a startup, and
you're going back to 0, you're just not
moving fast enough.

So if you could
leverage a platform-- In a lot of ways,
companies 20 years ago would do this with Oracle.

They'd just take the Oracle
Database and they'd be like, OK, we're just building
on top of Oracle. I think today that would be
a Databricks or something
equivalent.
